cluster_relations.rel_desc: The austenitic structure is normally found in 300 Series austenitic stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels

remarks: Complements the alloy→structure relation by capturing where the structure is typically present.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Ferritic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Redundant with the duplex→ferritic structural relation but captures the inverse perspective (where ferritic is found).

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic structure occurs as one phase within duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

remarks: Inverse perspective of the duplex→austenitic structural relation, included for coverage of where the austenitic phase is found.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization occurs in low alloy C-Mo steels containing up to 1% Mo.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ObservationContext: field or service experience

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules are present in carbon steels as products of carbide decomposition at elevated temperatures.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: decomposition of carbide phases

remarks: Subjective mapping of the pronoun “these steels” to carbon steels; 0.5Mo steels are handled in a separate relation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphite nodules can also occur in 0.5Mo steels under elevated temperature conditions.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Origin: carbide phase decomposition associated with graphitization

remarks: Moderate uncertainty because the pronoun could be read as all previously mentioned affected steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a microstructure, damage mechanism, process, or product phase occurs in or is present within a given material or alloy family.
args.justification: In all instances, the subject is a structure, mechanism, process, or product (e.g., austenitic structure, ferritic structure, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) and the object is a material or alloy class (e.g., austenitic stainless steels, duplex stainless steel, low alloy steel, carbon steel). The semantics are consistently that the phenomenon occurs in or is present within that material. A single canonical predicate 'occurs_in_material' captures this shared meaning while remaining specific to occurrence within materials.

Each relation links a phenomenon (microstructure, cracking mechanism, degradation process, or product phase) to a material or alloy where it occurs. Grouping them under a broader class 'phenomenon_occurrence_in_material_relation' captures this family of predicates without being as broad as a generic spatial or association relation.

The core semantics are about where a phenomenon is present (i.e., its occurrence within a particular material or alloy), which fits a broad spatial/contextual dimension better than causality or composition. Therefore these relations belong under the SPATIALITY group.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a microstructure, damage mechanism, process, or product phase occurs in or is present within a given material or alloy family.
executed_decisions.justification: In all instances, the subject is a structure, mechanism, process, or product (e.g., austenitic structure, ferritic structure, HIC, graphitization, graphite nodules) and the object is a material or alloy class (e.g., austenitic stainless steels, duplex stainless steel, low alloy steel, carbon steel). The semantics are consistently that the phenomenon occurs in or is present within that material. A single canonical predicate 'occurs_in_material' captures this shared meaning while remaining specific to occurrence within materials.

Each relation links a phenomenon (microstructure, cracking mechanism, degradation process, or product phase) to a material or alloy where it occurs. Grouping them under a broader class 'phenomenon_occurrence_in_material_relation' captures this family of predicates without being as broad as a generic spatial or association relation.

The core semantics are about where a phenomenon is present (i.e., its occurrence within a particular material or alloy), which fits a broad spatial/contextual dimension better than causality or composition. Therefore these relations belong under the SPATIALITY group.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to oxidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are resistant to sulfidation due to their alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MechanismType: corrosion mechanism

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels resist various forms of general corrosion, beyond just oxidation and sulfidation, depending on alloy content.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: other forms of corrosion beyond oxidation and sulfidation

remarks: Relation generalized from phrase 'other forms of corrosion' to entity 'general corrosion'.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against sulfidation.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium contributes to resistance to general corrosion forms when used as an alloying element in stainless steels.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels; depending on the alloy content
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Scope: general corrosion (other forms of corrosion)

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that chromium helps overall corrosion resistance; semantics slightly generalized.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Adding approximately 0.7% chromium to low alloy C-Mo steels eliminates graphitization.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: addition of about 0.7% chromium; steels with up to 1% Mo

remarks: Material context (low alloy C-Mo steels with up to 1% Mo) added as qualifiers rather than as extra entities.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion or degradation mechanism under certain conditions.
args.justification: All three relations link stainless steel to specific or generalized corrosion mechanisms and describe the material's resistance to those mechanisms, differing only in the corrosion type (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion). They share the same predicate semantics: the material resists the mechanism.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to the resistance of a material system against a specified corrosion or degradation mechanism.
args.justification: These three relations consistently describe chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, causally contributing to resistance against oxidation, sulfidation, or general corrosion. The subject is not the resisting bulk material but the element that provides resistance, so a causal resistance predicate distinct from plain 'resists' is appropriate.
args.remark: Context that chromium acts via stainless steel is already captured in qualifiers and does not change the predicate direction.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject inhibits or effectively eliminates the occurrence of the specified degradation or metallurgical process under the stated conditions.
args.justification: This relation describes chromium addition eliminating (inhibiting) graphitization in low alloy C-Mo steels. The semantics are direct prevention of a degradation process rather than generic resistance, so a predicate 'prevents' accurately captures the inhibitory effect.

All relations connect materials or alloying elements to corrosion or degradation mechanisms (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion, graphitization) and describe resistance or prevention. Despite different surface predicates ('resists', 'provides_resistance_to', 'prevents'), they share the same conceptual class: the subject mitigates or inhibits a degradation mechanism.

Each relation expresses a causal influence of a material or alloying element on the occurrence or severity of a degradation mechanism: materials resisting mechanisms and alloying elements providing resistance or preventing processes. This is best captured under a causal relation group rather than mere association.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Subject material exhibits resistance to the specified corrosion or degradation mechanism under certain conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: All three relations link stainless steel to specific or generalized corrosion mechanisms and describe the material's resistance to those mechanisms, differing only in the corrosion type (oxidation, sulfidation, general corrosion). They share the same predicate semantics: the material resists the mechanism.

The subject is not the resisting bulk material but the element that provides resistance, so a causal resistance predicate distinct from plain 'resists' is appropriate.
executed_decisions.remark: Context that chromium acts via stainless steel is already captured in qualifiers and does not change the predicate direction.

The semantics are direct prevention of a degradation process rather than generic resistance, so a predicate 'prevents' accurately captures the inhibitory effect.

Despite different surface predicates ('resists', 'provides_resistance_to', 'prevents'), they share the same conceptual class: the subject mitigates or inhibits a degradation mechanism.

Each relation expresses a causal influence of a material or alloying element on the occurrence or severity of a degradation mechanism: materials resisting mechanisms and alloying elements providing resistance or preventing processes. This is best captured under a causal relation group rather than mere association.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: mechanical property degradation

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.
remarks: Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).
args.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of different steels under long-term high-temperature operation; they share the same direction (process → material) and semantic meaning of microstructural alteration.

args.canonical_rel_desc: A process or transformation leads to the formation of a specific microstructural constituent or feature within a material (e.g., graphite nodules, carbides, precipitates).
args.justification: This relation specifically captures that graphitization produces/creates graphite nodules as microstructural features in the steel, which is more precise than a generic 'produces' predicate.

All three relations describe how the graphitization process changes or generates microstructural features in steels (altering existing microstructure or forming graphite nodules), so they belong to the same broader class of microstructural transformation relations.

Each relation expresses that a process (graphitization) modifies the state of a material by changing its microstructure or forming new microstructural constituents, fitting a broad modification/change-of-state dimension rather than simple association or identity.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).
executed_decisions.justification: Both relations describe graphitization changing the microstructure of different steels under long-term high-temperature operation; they share the same direction (process → material) and semantic meaning of microstructural alteration.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: A process or transformation leads to the formation of a specific microstructural constituent or feature within a material (e.g., graphite nodules, carbides, precipitates).
executed_decisions.justification: This relation specifically captures that graphitization produces/creates graphite nodules as microstructural features in the steel, which is more precise than a generic 'produces' predicate.

Each relation expresses that a process (graphitization) modifies the state of a material by changing its microstructure or forming new microstructural constituents, fitting a broad modification/change-of-state dimension rather than simple association or identity.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Methyldiethanolamine and monoethanolamine are both used in amine treating to remove H2S and CO2 from hydrocarbon streams, indicating they serve similar functional roles and can be alternatives to each other.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is one of the four categories of stainless steels listed.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two materials or chemicals can serve the same functional role in a given application and may be substituted for one another.
args.justification: The relation connects two amine treating chemicals that serve the same role in removing H2S and CO2, implying they are interchangeable in function; a symmetric predicate expressing functional substitution is appropriate.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject material class has the object as a more specific subtype or category within it.
args.justification: The subject is the broader class (Stainless Steel) and the object is a specific category (duplex stainless steel); this is the superclass-to-subclass direction, best captured as 'has_subtype'.
args.remark: Inverse of 'is_subtype_of'; kept explicitly to allow both hierarchy directions in the KG.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
args.justification: Duplex stainless steel is explicitly described as a category within the broader class of stainless steels, matching a subtype-to-supertype taxonomic relation.

Both relations describe hierarchical category membership between a specific stainless steel type and the general stainless steel class; they are instances of the same taxonomic hierarchy family (supertype–subtype).
The link expresses that two chemicals fulfill the same industrial function and can act as substitutes; this is more specific than generic similarity and fits a substitution-oriented relation class.
Subtype/supertype relations are about defining what something is in a classification system, i.e., its taxonomic identity, not composition, causality, or usage.

The alternative relationship is grounded in the shared industrial use (amine treating of hydrocarbon streams), reflecting how the chemicals are used rather than their intrinsic identity or composition.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two materials or chemicals can serve the same functional role in a given application and may be substituted for one another.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation connects two amine treating chemicals that serve the same role in removing H2S and CO2, implying they are interchangeable in function; a symmetric predicate expressing functional substitution is appropriate.

executed_decisions.remark: Inverse of 'is_subtype_of'; kept explicitly to allow both hierarchy directions in the KG.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.
executed_decisions.justification: Duplex stainless steel is explicitly described as a category within the broader class of stainless steels, matching a subtype-to-supertype taxonomic relation.

The alternative relationship is grounded in the shared industrial use (amine treating of hydrocarbon streams), reflecting how the chemicals are used rather than their intrinsic identity or composition.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Mechanical and Metallurgical Failure and Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: listed as peer damage mechanism categories in the same section

remarks: Relation reflects document-level grouping rather than a causal or hierarchical dependency; direction is arbitrary and used only to encode co-membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness and High Temperature Corrosion are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.subject_entity_name: Uniform or Localized Loss of Thickness

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: co-listed as damage mechanism categories

remarks: Relation mainly encodes co-membership in the same list; not implying any causal or structural dependency between the mechanisms.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: High Temperature Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking are presented as peer sections within the same list of damage mechanisms.
cluster_relations.object_class_label: Stress Corrosion and Environment Assisted Cracking Mechanisms

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DocumentStructure: both are subsections under the same damage mechanisms section

remarks: Relation created to capture that both mechanisms are co-classified in the same document section; direction is arbitrary.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two concepts are presented as peer categories or sections within the same classification or list (e.g., in a document), without implying causal, hierarchical, or structural dependency.
args.justification: All three relations describe damage mechanism categories that are presented as peer sections within the same document list/section. The semantics are symmetric co-membership in a classification structure, not causality or hierarchy. A normalized predicate 'co_classified_with' better captures this document-structure-based association than the raw label and can be reused consistently.
args.remark: Direction is arbitrary; the predicate should be interpreted as symmetric.

args.justification: Each relation instance encodes that two damage mechanisms are co-listed or co-sectioned in the same document classification (peer sections in a list of mechanisms). This is best modeled as a document-level co-classification family rather than causal, compositional, or hierarchical relations.

The relations express that entities are associated by being co-members of the same document-defined list or section, not that they are identical, causal, temporal, or spatially related. This fits a broad ASSOCIATION group.

executed_decisions.remark: Direction is arbitrary; the predicate should be interpreted as symmetric.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Austenitic stainless steels are characterized by an austenitic metallurgical structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: AlloyScope: 300 Series stainless steels including Types 304, 304L, 304H, 309, 310, 316, 316L, 316H, 321, 321H, 347, and 347H

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have an austenitic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steels have a ferritic component in their mixed austenitic-ferritic structure.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureType: mixed austenitic-ferritic

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having an austenitic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels are categorized based on having a ferritic metallurgical structure at room temperature.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates the metallurgical/microstructural phase type (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic, or mixed) that characterizes a metal or alloy under specified conditions.
args.justification: All these relations link a steel or alloy category (subject) to its metallurgical/microstructural phase type (object), such as austenitic, ferritic, or martensitic, sometimes with qualifiers like temperature or mixed structures. They share the same predicate semantics and can be normalized to a single canonical relation.

Each relation expresses how a steel or alloy is characterized by a specific metallurgical/microstructural structure. Grouping them under a common class for metallurgical structure relations captures this shared semantics and can support other related predicates about microstructure in the future.

These predicates describe structural/microstructural characteristics (phase structure) of materials rather than composition, causality, or identity. A broad group label of STRUCTURE best reflects their role in the KG.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates the metallurgical/microstructural phase type (e.g., austenitic, ferritic, martensitic, or mixed) that characterizes a metal or alloy under specified conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: All these relations link a steel or alloy category (subject) to its metallurgical/microstructural phase type (object), such as austenitic, ferritic, or martensitic, sometimes with qualifiers like temperature or mixed structures. They share the same predicate semantics and can be normalized to a single canonical relation.

Each relation expresses how a steel or alloy is characterized by a specific metallurgical/microstructural structure. Grouping them under a common class for metallurgical structure relations captures this shared semantics and can support other related predicates about microstructure in the future.

These predicates describe structural/microstructural characteristics (phase structure) of materials rather than composition, causality, or identity. A broad group label of STRUCTURE best reflects their role in the KG.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Welds of austenitic stainless steels may exhibit a duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) structure, linking them conceptually to duplex stainless steels.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: in welds of 300 Series stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: MicrostructureContext: weld metal/heat-affected zone duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure

remarks: Relation created mainly to capture that welds of austenitic stainless steels can show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure; semantic mapping to the duplex stainless steel family is approximate.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Stainless steels contain varying amounts of chromium as an alloying element.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CompositionContext: alloy content in stainless steels

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two material classes are conceptually related because they can exhibit similar or analogous microstructural features under certain conditions.
args.justification: The relation describes that welds of austenitic stainless steels may show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure, conceptually linking them to duplex stainless steels. This is not strict equivalence or hierarchy but a similarity in microstructural behavior. A predicate explicitly capturing microstructural similarity is most appropriate.
args.remark: This captures an approximate, condition-dependent similarity in microstructure rather than a strict classification link.

args.justification: The connection is based on similarity of duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure between austenitic stainless steel welds and duplex stainless steels, fitting a class focused on microstructural similarity between materials.

The relation is fundamentally about microstructural characteristics (austenitic-ferritic duplex structure), which falls under a structural/microstructural dimension rather than composition, causality, or hierarchy.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that an alloy or material contains a given chemical element as part of its intentional alloy composition.
args.justification: The instance describes stainless steels containing chromium as an alloying element. The existing raw relation_name already closely matches the intended semantics, so it is appropriate to normalize and adopt it as the canonical predicate for composition via alloying elements.
This relation connects an alloy class (stainless steel) to a specific alloying element (chromium), which is a canonical example of an alloying-element-based composition relation.
The relation is explicitly about which element is present in the material's composition and in what varying amounts, fitting the COMPOSITION dimension.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two material classes are conceptually related because they can exhibit similar or analogous microstructural features under certain conditions.
executed_decisions.justification: The relation describes that welds of austenitic stainless steels may show a duplex (austenitic-ferritic) structure, conceptually linking them to duplex stainless steels. This is not strict equivalence or hierarchy but a similarity in microstructural behavior. A predicate explicitly capturing microstructural similarity is most appropriate.
executed_decisions.remark: This captures an approximate, condition-dependent similarity in microstructure rather than a strict classification link.

executed_decisions.justification: The connection is based on similarity of duplex-type (austenitic-ferritic) microstructure between austenitic stainless steel welds and duplex stainless steels, fitting a class focused on microstructural similarity between materials.

The relation is fundamentally about microstructural characteristics (austenitic-ferritic duplex structure), which falls under a structural/microstructural dimension rather than composition, causality, or hierarchy.
